title: 113_hr1222
content: The Act may be cited as the "Compact-Impact Aid Act of 2013" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Congress finds that the Compact of Free Association was not intended to harm US states and territories, and if adverse consequences arise, Congress will address them promptly. The Government Accountability Office has noted significant impacts on Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, Hawaii, and some parts of the US due to migration from the Freely Associated States. The Compact of Free Association has adversely affected the budgetary resources of several States and territories by placing demands on local governments for health, educational, and social services. Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and Hawaii have faced increased costs due to individuals from the Federated States of Micronesia, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Republic of Palau. The purpose of this Act is to address the unfunded mandate and adverse financial consequences resulting from the Compact. The Act aims to address the financial burden on states and territories caused by the Compact of Free Association, specifically focusing on mandatory appropriations and health services reimbursement. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to address impact costs related to migration from the Federated States of Micronesia and the Republic of Palau. $185,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2013 with potential increases to assist local governments in the United States facing financial strain due to increased immigration. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to address impact costs related to migration from Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, and Palau. $185,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2013 to assist local governments in the United States facing financial strain due to increased immigration. Grants will be awarded and administered by the Department of the Interior for services and infrastructure related to qualified nonimmigrants. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to address impact costs related to migration from Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, and Palau. $185,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2013 to assist local governments in the United States facing financial strain due to increased immigration. Grants will be awarded and administered by the Department of the Interior for services and infrastructure related to qualified nonimmigrants, with periodic enumerations conducted by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct periodic enumerations supervised by the United States Bureau of the Census or another selected organization. Grants will be allocated to qualified affected areas based on the number of qualified immigrants. The Secretary of the Interior conducts periodic enumerations of immigrants in different jurisdictions. Grants are allocated based on the number of immigrants in each area. Nonimmigrants receive medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Federal medical assistance percentage for individuals receiving services through an Indian Health Service Facility shall be the same as for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Payments for medical assistance for qualified nonimmigrants shall not count towards any limitations under section 1108 of the Social Security Act. A qualified nonimmigrant is defined as a person admitted to the US under section 141 of the Compact of Free Association. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985, as amended, applies to medical assistance for items and services provided during or after fiscal year 2013.
